alert.note: Alert for Humboldt County; Northeastern Nye County; Northern Elko County; Northern Lander County and Northern Eureka County; Northwestern Nye County; Ruby Mountains and East Humboldt Range; South Central Elko County; Southeastern Elko County; Southern Lander County and Southern Eureka County; Southwest Elko County; White Pine County (Nevada) Issued by the National Weather Service

info.headline: Special Weather Statement issued February 20 at 2:38PM PST by NWS Elko
info.description: ...Winter weather makes a return tonight through Wednesday... Winter-like conditions will be returning to northern and central Nevada beginning tonight. The snow showers will be around through mid-week along with much colder temperatures. A cold front will push across the area tonight. Any valley rain showers that develop will quickly turn over to snow as temperatures drop behind the cold front. Initial amounts for tonight into Monday evening are a little higher than previous forecast, especially along the US Highway 50 corridor. Amounts there will be in the 1 to 4 inch range, though outside of this area, many valley locations will see up to an inch. Snow showers will continue each afternoon with light amounts expected. For the entire period Tuesday through Wednesday, valley locations could see up to an inch to possibly three inches in localized areas, while the mountains are expected to see three to six inches through the entire mid-week period. Winds will also become breezy to windy from the west and southwest this evening with gusty northerly winds behind the cold front tomorrow across central Nevada. Some spots of blowing and drifting snow are possible, especially on higher passes and summits. Temperatures will be below normal for tomorrow and those are expected to continue through the mid-week with highs below freezing in many locations Wednesday and lows in some valleys Thursday morning well into the single digits. Motorists should remain alert to rapidly changing weather, and take necessary precautions if travel is necessary. Visit www.weather.gov/elko for the latest weather information.
